{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2016}} {{Use American English|date=July 2016}} [[File:Johnson's Baby Product Shelves at Kroger.JPG|thumb|right|upright=1.36|Johnson's Baby products at Kroger]]
'''Johnson's Baby''' is an American brand of baby [[cosmetics]] and skin care products owned by [[Johnson & Johnson]]. The brand dates back to 1893 when Johnson's Baby Powder was introduced. Product line consists of [[baby powder]], [[shampoo]]s, body [[lotion]]s, massage oil, shower gels and [[Wet wipe#Baby wipes|baby wipes]]. The brand has reputation for making baby products that are "exceptionally pure and safe" since at least the 1980s.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/magazine/beauty-the-boom-in-no-frills-cosmetics.html |title = Beauty; THE BOOM IN NO-FRILLS COSMETICS |date = February 8, 1981 |publisher = The New York Times |accessdate = August 5, 2014 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Rbr21OJ0?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1981/02/08/magazine/beauty-the-boom-in-no-frills-cosmetics.html |archivedate = August 5, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
== History ==
=== Johnson's Baby Powder and sanitary napkins (1893) ===
[[File:Johnsons Baby Powder 1,5 OZS talc, pic5.JPG|thumb|right|Johnson's Baby Powder (20th century)]]
[[File:Johnsons Baby Powder massage.jpg|thumb|right|Johnson's Baby Powder (2014)]]
Johnson's Baby Powder was an invention of Dr. [[Frederick Barnett Kilmer|Frederick B. Kilmer]], company's first director of scientific affairs.<ref>{{cite book |last = Turner |first = Tyya |date = 2007 |title = Vault Guide to the Top Consumer Products Employers |url = https://books.google.com/?id=aT59Q0J1QV0C&printsec=frontcover&dq=Vault+Guide+to+the+Top+Consumer+Products+Employers#v=onepage&q=kilmer&f=false |publisher = Vault |page = 185 |isbn = 978-1-58131-323-9 |accessdate = August 3, 2014 }}</ref> In 1892 he got a letter from a physician noting that patient suffered skin irritations after using medicated plasters. Kilmer suggested to use scented Italian [[talc]]um powder to mitigate the irritation and sent a can to the doctor.<ref>{{cite book |last = Oppenheimer |first = Jerry |date = 2013 |title = Crazy Rich: Power, Scandal and Tragedy Inside the Johnson and Johnson Dynasty |url = https://books.google.com/?id=17q2qiDwhyQC&printsec=frontcover&dq=jerry+oppenheimer#v=onepage&q=kilmer&f=false |publisher = St. Martin's Press |page = 46 |isbn = 978-0-312-66211-0 |accessdate = August 3, 2014 }}</ref>
Baby Powder debuted in 1893 and went to the market in 1894.<ref name="kilmerhouse">{{cite web |url = http://www.kilmerhouse.com/2007/04/the-birth-of-our-baby-products/ |title = The Birth of Our Baby Products |author = Margaret Gurowitz |date = April 30, 2007 |publisher = Kilmerhouse.com |accessdate = August 3, 2014 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6RXvDOkzp?url=http://www.kilmerhouse.com/2007/04/the-birth-of-our-baby-products/ |archivedate = August 3, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref> The earliest Baby Powder was in a yellow and red tin with a label "For Toilet and Nursery”.<ref name="kilmerhouse" />
According to Robert Shook, sanitary napkins were included in the young mother's kit but never considered a separate product until customers asked the company for it. {{quote|quote=In 1893 the talc was packaged in a box that was originally distributed to midwives and given to mothers following childbirth. The mothers liked it so much, the company started to sell it in drugstores. Also in the midwife's box were twelve sanitary napkins. Prior to this, there was no such product available to purchase. After the company received hundreds of letter from women wanting to know where they could buy these products, the company started to manufacture them – the first company to make sanitary napkins in the United States.<ref>{{cite book |last = Shook |first = Robert L. |date = 2007 |title = Miracle Medicines: Seven Lifesaving Drugs and the People Who Created Them |url = https://books.google.com/?id=3f7rnSnP7LUC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Miracle+Medicines:+Seven+Lifesaving+Drugs+and+the+People+Who+Created+Them#v=onepage&q=Baby%20Powder&f=false |publisher = Penguin Group |isbn = 978-1-4406-9607-7 |accessdate = August 3, 2014 }}</ref>}}
The first baby to appear on Johnson's Baby powder label was [[Mary Lea Johnson Richards]], granddaughter of [[Robert Wood Johnson I]] (co-founder of [[Johnson & Johnson]]).<ref name=NYMag>{{cite book |url = https://books.google.com/?id=peMCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA129&lpg=PA129#v=onepage&q&f=false |title = Crazier Than You and Me |author = Rhoda Koenig |date = February 23, 1987 |publisher = [[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]] |accessdate = November 25, 2014 }} (Google Books)</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/nyregion/about-books.html?scp=3&sq=mary%20lea%20johnson&st=cse |title=About books |author=Shirley Horner |date=February 15, 1987 |publisher=The New York Times |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6UKj5BiTc?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1987/02/15/nyregion/about-books.html?scp=3 |archivedate=November 24, 2014 |accessdate=November 25, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Johnson's Baby Powder has a particular scent that for many Americans is associated with the smell of the baby itself. According to Johnson & Johnson's representative Fred Tewell (cited by [[Toronto Star]]), baby powder-scented cleaning products became almost a standard not only to cosmetics, but to diapers as well. And all Johnson's Baby products have a "powdery" note in them.<ref name="tstar">{{cite web |url = https://www.thestar.com/life/2008/04/18/smelling_like_a_baby.html |title = Smelling like a baby: now at the grownup fragrance counter – the scent of a baby |author = Samantha Critchell |date = April 18, 2008 |publisher = [[Toronto Star]] |accessdate = August 6, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140806191519/http://www.thestar.com/life/2008/04/18/smelling_like_a_baby.html |archivedate = August 6, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
=== Johnson's Baby Cream (1921) ===
Johnson's Baby cream was introduced in 1921.<ref>{{cite book |last = Meyer |first = Thomas A. |date = 2010 |title = Innovate!: How Great Companies Get Started in Terrible Times |url = https://books.google.com/?id=2CWkH2peM6MC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Innovate!:+How+Great+Companies+Get+Started+in+Terrible+Times#v=onepage&q=baby%20cream&f=false |publisher = John Wiley & Sons |page = 74 |isbn = 978-0-470-56058-7 |accessdate = August 3, 2014 }}</ref>
=== The Gift Box (1921) ===
According to Margaret Gurowitz, Johnson & Johnson's corporate historian, in 1921 the company released its first "Baby Gift Box" that contained small packages of Baby Powder, Baby Cream and Baby Soap and "was designed as a small gift that people could take when visiting a family with a new baby".<ref name="kilmerhouse" />
=== Johnson's Baby oil (1938) ===
Introduced in 1938<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.yahoo.com/beauty/old-school-products-that-still-rock-88003401298.html |title = Old School Products That Still Rock |author = Joanna Douglas |quote = Back in 1938 this was a must-have for newborns, but nowadays people of all ages have a million and one uses for oil. Among them: sealing in moisture post-shower, removing makeup, relieving dry skin, extending the life of fragrances, adding a subtle shine to your hair, and taking off wax, grease or other sticky things from your skin — all while smelling incredible. |date = June 16, 2014 |publisher = [[Yahoo!]] |accessdate = August 6, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140806184639/https://www.yahoo.com/beauty/old-school-products-that-still-rock-88003401298.html |archivedate = August 6, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.facebook.com/201881730533/posts/10151300360515534/ |title = Introduction of JOHNSON’S® Baby Oil (February 23, 1938) |publisher = Johnson's Baby [[Facebook]] page |accessdate = August 6, 2014 }}</ref> Johnson's Baby massage oil was heavily advertised nationwide ("Life" magazine<ref>{{Cite book |url = https://books.google.com/?id=T1AEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA6&dq=Johnson%27s+Baby+oil#v=onepage&q=Johnson's%20Baby%20oil&f=false |title = Page 6 |date = August 9, 1943 |publisher = [[Life (magazine)|LIFE]] |accessdate = August 3, 2014 }}</ref>) since 1943 as a complementary product to Baby Powder.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.newspapers.com/newspage/58361140/ |title = Page 4 |date = February 25, 1943 |publisher = The Evening News from Harrisburg, Pennsylvania |quote = JOHNSON'S BABY GIFT SET For any lucky baby! Contain. John' son. Baby powder, oil, cream, soap |accessdate = August 3, 2014 }}</ref>
=== Johnson's Baby Lotion (1942) ===
Often referred as the "Pink Brand"<ref name="shrimp">{{cite book |last1 = Shrimp |first1 = Terence |last2 = Andrews |first2 = J. Craig |date = 2013 |title = Advertising Promotion and Other Aspects of Integrated Marketing Communications |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=HTcWAAAAQBAJ&pg=PA361&lpg=PA361#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher = Cengage Learning |page = 361 |isbn = 978-1-111-58021-6 |accessdate = August 6, 2014 }}</ref> (after the color of the bottle), Johnson's Baby Lotion appeared in 1942.<ref name="tstar" /><ref name="shrimp" />
=== Johnson's Baby Shampoo (1953) ===
[[File:No More Tears Ad 1956.jpg|thumb|right|"No More Tears" Johnson's Baby shampoo advertising from the "Family Circle" magazine (1956)]]
[[File:Johnsons Baby Empty.jpg|thumb|right|Baby reaching for the empty bottle of "No More Tears" shampoo while bathing]]
"No More Tears" shampoo was introduced in 1953.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://ideas.time.com/2012/08/22/the-real-lesson-of-formaldehyde-in-baby-shampoo/ |title = The Real Lesson of Formaldehyde In Baby Shampoo |author = Dominique Browning |date = August 22, 2012 |publisher = [[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate = August 3, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140803085226/http://ideas.time.com/2012/08/22/the-real-lesson-of-formaldehyde-in-baby-shampoo/ |archivedate = August 3, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
As noted by Nunes and Johnson:
{{quote|quote=In 1953 Johnson & Johnson introduced its No More Tears baby shampoo. Targeting this particular use involved a real soap breakthrough, however, with the company introducing [[Amphoterism|amphoteric]] cleansing agents to consumer use. Though these agents are not as effective as traditional soaps, they are extremely mild, which makes them quite literally ''easy on the eyes'' and perfect for a baby's sensitive but presumably not-too-dirty skin. Designing this new category of cleaners for this user segment enabled Johnson & Johnson to capture a category it still dominates today, more than fifty years later. Within six months of its introduction, Johnson & Johnson had captured 75 percent of the baby shampoo market, a share it held as recently as 1995.<ref>{{cite book |last1 = Nunes |first1 = Paul |last2 = Johnson |first2 = Brian |date = 2004 |title = Mass Affluence: Seven New Rules of Marketing to Today's Consumer |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=LLmU8dWCem4C&pg=PA95&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false |publisher = Harvard Business Review Press |page = 95 |isbn = 978-1-59139-196-8 |accessdate = August 5, 2014 }}</ref>}}
In 1955 [[Johnson & Johnson]] placed advertising at the "[[The Adventures of Robin Hood (TV series)|Adventures of Robin Hood]] TV series for [[Band-Aid]] and Johnson's baby shampoo. The later was advertised with the tagline "Johnson's can't burn eyes".<ref>{{cite AV media |year = 1955 |title = Adventures of Robin Hood (1955–59) Complete Open (J&J) |url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=KyCFHm5LnDA |access-date = June 28, 2015 }}</ref>
"No More Tears" has been registered as a trademark only since 1959.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://trademarks.justia.com/722/01/no-more-tears-72201033.html |title = NO MORE TEARS – Trademark Details |publisher = Justia.com |accessdate = August 8, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140807204305/http://trademarks.justia.com/722/01/no-more-tears-72201033.html |archivedate=August 7, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
=== No More Tangles (1971) ===
"No More Tangles" shampoo (named after popular "No More Tears" shampoo) debuted in 1971.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.facebook.com/201881730533/posts/10151299980920534/ |title = Introduction of JOHNSON’S® Baby NO MORE TANGLES® (December 4, 1971) |publisher = Johnson's Baby [[Facebook]] page |accessdate = August 6, 2014 }}</ref>
=== Book publishing (1976) ===
In 1976 the brand entered publishing business with the book "Infant development program: birth-12 months" by Richard A. Chase,<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.worldcat.org/title/infant-development-program-birth-12-months/oclc/4818230 |title = Infant development program: birth-12 months |publisher = [[OCLC]] |accessdate = October 3, 2015 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151004202537/http://www.worldcat.org/title/infant-development-program-birth-12-months/oclc/4818230 |archivedate=October 4, 2015 |deadurl = no }}</ref> followed by "The First wondrous year: you and your baby" (1979) by Chase and Richard R. Rubin.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.worldcat.org/title/first-wondrous-year-you-and-your-baby/oclc/5495957 |title = The First wondrous year: you and your baby |publisher = [[OCLC]] |accessdate = October 3, 2015 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151004202939/http://www.worldcat.org/title/first-wondrous-year-you-and-your-baby/oclc/5495957 |archivedate=October 4, 2015 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
=== Johnson's Baby Wipes (1980) ===
Johnson's baby wipes appeared in 1980 as Johnson's Baby Wash Cloths.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1964&dat=19800717&id=aP4sAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qswFAAAAIBAJ&pg=2920,3988141 |title = Get your baby wash cloth clean at every diaper change |date = July 17, 1980 |publisher = [[The Palm Beach Post]] |accessdate = December 12, 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref>
The product was renamed "[[Wet wipe#Baby wipes|wipes]]" sometime during 90s (the product has already been present as early as 1990<ref>{{cite book |last1 = Biracree |first1 = Tom |last2 = Biracree |first2 = Nancy |year = 1990 |title = Buying the Best for Your Baby |publisher = Knightsbridge Publishing Company Trade |isbn = 1-877961-69-8 |page = 123 }}</ref>). In 1994 it was advertised as a better option for cleansing baby skin than [[water]] due to mild, [[pH]]-neutral cleansing lotion that wipes contain.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?nid=1295&dat=19941218&id=y_lNAAAAIBAJ&sjid=jRMEAAAAIBAJ&pg=5353,3718555 |title = Water alone does not provide total cleansing |date = December 18, 1994 |publisher = [[New Straits Times|New Sunday Times]] |accessdate = December 12, 2014 }}</ref>
=== Sun Screen (1991) ===
Sun screen was introduced in Spring 1991.<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/business/creating-the-well-groomed-child.html |title = Creating the Well-Groomed Child |author = Stephanie Strom |date = July 6, 1991 |publisher = The New York Times |accessdate = August 5, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140805215719/http://www.nytimes.com/1991/07/06/business/creating-the-well-groomed-child.html |archivedate = August 5, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
=== Head-To-Toe Cleanser (1997) ===
Head-To-Toe ultra mild [[cleanser]] was introduced in 1997.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.facebook.com/201881730533/posts/10151298735230534/ |title = Introduction of JOHNSON’S® Baby HEAD-TO-TOE® Wash (December 12, 1997) |publisher = Johnson's Baby [[Facebook]] page |accessdate = August 8, 2014 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://tmsearch.uspto.gov/bin/showfield?f=doc&state=4809:om6vu9.2.5 |title=Johnson's head-to-toe |publisher=[[United States Patent and Trademark Office]] |accessdate=June 28, 2015 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ZcTP4vAf?url=http://tmsearch.uspto.gov/bin/showfield?f=doc |archivedate=June 28, 2015 |deadurl=no |df= }}</ref>
=== Bedtime range (2000) ===
Bedtime Bath introduced in 2000<ref>{{cite web |url = https://www.facebook.com/201881730533/posts/10151298721235534/ |title = Introduction of JOHNSON’S® Baby BEDTIME® BATH (May 10, 2000) |publisher = Johnson's Baby [[Facebook]] page |accessdate = August 8, 2014 }}</ref> was the first of products later known as Johnson’s Baby Bedtime range with four products (Bedtime Bath, Bedtime Lotion, Bedtime Wash and Bedtime Oil) that contain [[lavender]] and [[camomile]].<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.cosmeticsbusiness.com/technical/article_page/Baby_toiletries__Cradle_to_cradle/47662 |title = Baby toiletries – Cradle to cradle |date = July 13, 2010 |publisher = Cosmetics Business |accessdate = August 8, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140807210253/http://www.cosmeticsbusiness.com/technical/article_page/Baby_toiletries__Cradle_to_cradle/47662 |archivedate=August 7, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
In 2001 Bedtime lotion was advertised in magazines like "Working Mom Magazine" as "The world's first lullaby in a lotion".<ref>{{cite web |url = https://books.google.com/books?id=avKwKDzlTY0C&pg=PA54&dq=#v=onepage&q&f=false |title = world's first lullaby in a lotion |date = June 2001 |publisher = Working Mom, #6 |accessdate = June 28, 2015 }}</ref>
=== "So much more" campaign (2015) ===
In 2015 the brand launched the "So much more" campaign focused on multi-sensory experiences (such as a massage during bathing<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.cbsnews.com/news/johnson-baby-wash-commercial-star-monterey-stealing-hearts-around-world/ |title = Meet the adorable new face of Johnson's Baby Wash |date = September 7, 2015 |publisher = [[CBS News]] |accessdate = October 4, 2015 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20151004205505/http://www.cbsnews.com/news/johnson-baby-wash-commercial-star-monterey-stealing-hearts-around-world/ |archivedate = October 4, 2015 |deadurl = no }}</ref>) highlighting the benefits of such experiences for baby's development.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2015/02/04/jjs-baby-unit-launches-new-campaign-to-show-baths-are-so-much-more/ |title = J&J’s Baby Unit Launches New Campaign to Show Baths are ‘So Much More’ |author = Nathalie Tadena |date = February 4, 2015 |publisher = The Wall Street Journal |accessdate = June 28, 2015 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6Zcb66PBT?url=https://blogs.wsj.com/cmo/2015/02/04/jjs-baby-unit-launches-new-campaign-to-show-baths-are-so-much-more/ |archivedate = June 28, 2015 |deadurl = no }}</ref>
== Marketing baby products to adults ==
The company has been using "Best for the Baby – Best for You" tagline since the early days. Some examples of such advertising can be spotted as early as 1913, when only Johnson's Baby Powder existed.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=2SkuAAAAIBAJ&sjid=29QFAAAAIBAJ&pg=4810%2C820658 |title = The Red Cross Pharmacy |date = January 13, 1913 |publisher = [[The Miami News]] |quote = Johnson's Toilet and Baby Powder. Best for Baby and Best for You. The Purest Toilet Powder that it is possiblt to manufacture" |accessdate = August 8, 2014 }}{{Dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref>
Sometime in the beginning of 70s<ref>{{cite web |url = https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=D_wjAAAAIBAJ&sjid=62YEAAAAIBAJ&pg=6866%2C3789354 |title = Us Births Decline, Baby Businesses Grow |date = September 9, 1974 |publisher = [[Sarasota Herald-Tribune]] |quote = The company has produced heavy family-oriented advertising for the past few years" |accessdate = August 8, 2014 }}</ref> Johnson & Johnson started marketing baby products to families, promoting so-called "family usage".
The strategy has been a success. By the 80s Johnson's Baby grew market share in the adult market due to the perception that "baby products are milder than others".<ref name="nybaby">{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/19/magazine/babying-grown-ups.html |title = Babying grown-ups |author = Deborah Blumenthal |date = May 19, 1985 |publisher = The New York Times |accessdate = August 5, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140805213809/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/05/19/magazine/babying-grown-ups.html |archivedate = August 5, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref> In 1985, for instance, 70 percent of Johnson's Baby powder in the United States was used by adults.<ref name="nybaby" />
== Non-baby usage ==
Johnson's Baby products are widely used for non-baby occasions. For example, Johnson's [[Baby Oil]] is used as a facial [[cleanser]] (it has been reported by the "[[New York (magazine)|New York]]" magazine that popular TV talk show host [[Martha Stewart]] uses it this way<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/01/martha-stewarts-2000-beauty-regimen.html |title = Martha Stewart’s $2,000 Beauty Regimen |author = Kathleen Hou |date = January 9, 2014 |publisher = [[New York (magazine)|The Cut]] |accessdate = August 8, 2014 |archiveurl = https://www.webcitation.org/6RgAJCZtR?url=http://nymag.com/thecut/2014/01/martha-stewarts-2000-beauty-regimen.html |archivedate = August 8, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref>), by male [[stripper]]s<ref>{{cite web |url = http://nymag.com/thecut/2012/06/men-of-hunk-o-mania-on-grooming-routines.html |title = The Male Exotic Dancers of Hunk-A-Mania on Their Grooming Routines |author = Christina Han |date = June 28, 2012 |publisher = [[New York (magazine)|The Cut]] |accessdate = August 8, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140808175518/http://nymag.com/thecut/2012/06/men-of-hunk-o-mania-on-grooming-routines.html |archivedate = August 8, 2014 |deadurl = no }}</ref> as well as a [[lubricant]] in some sexual practices.
== Health risk issues ==
In December 1985 two physicians urged parents not to use baby powder, stating that it was unsafe to inhale and Johnson & Johnson responded with an official statement that "product is safe when used as it is intended".<ref>{{cite news |url = https://www.nytimes.com/1985/12/27/us/2-physicians-assert-baby-powder-can-endanger-infants-breathing.html |title = 2 physicians assert baby powder can endanger infants' breathing |date = December 27, 1985 |publisher = The New York Times |accessdate = August 5, 2014 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140805214512/http://www.nytimes.com/1985/12/27/us/2-physicians-assert-baby-powder-can-endanger-infants-breathing.html |archivedate = August 5, 2014 }}</ref>
In February 2016, J&J was ordered to pay $72 million in damages to the family of Jackie Fox, a 62-year-old woman who died of ovarian cancer in 2015. She had used Johnson's Baby Powder for many years. J&J claimed that the safety of cosmetic talc is supported by decades of scientific evidence and it plans to appeal the verdict. The British charity, Ovacome was quoted as saying that while there were 16 studies which showed that using talc increased the risk of ovarian cancer by around a third, and a 2013 review of US studies had similar results for genital, but not general, talcum powder use they were not convinced that the results were reliable. Furthermore, they said, "Ovarian cancer is a rare disease, and increasing a small risk by a third still gives a small risk."
== Clinical studies ==
In 2007 [[Johnson & Johnson]] sponsored "1st European Round Table meeting on 'Best Practice for Infant Cleansing" (a panel of expert dermatologists and paediatricians from across Europe) focused on the use of '''liquid cleansers''' in bathing as opposed to washing with water. It has been concluded that "bathing is generally superior to washing, provided basic safety procedures are followed, and has psychological benefits for the infant and parents".<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Blume-Peytavi |first1 = U |last2 = Cork |first2 = MJ |last3 = Faergemann |first3 = J |last4 = Szczapa |first4 = J |last5 = Vanaclocha |first5 = F |last6 = Gelmetti |first6 = C |title = Bathing and cleansing in newborns from day 1 to first year of life: recommendations from a European round table meeting |journal = Journal of the European Academy of Dermatology and Venereology |volume = 23 |issue = 7 |pages = 751–759 |date = June 3, 2009 |url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1468-3083.2009.03140.x/abstract |doi = 10.1111/j.1468-3083.2009.03140.x |pmid = 19646134 |accessdate = June 28, 2015 }}</ref>
A randomized clinical trial, sponsored by Johnson's baby brand in 2010 studied the effectiveness of using moisturizer as part of a standardized skin care regimen, for improving moisture levels in baby skin. Research showed that using '''baby lotion''' is effective for maintaining favorable moisture levels in baby skin (in comparison to not using baby lotion).<ref>{{cite journal |last1 = Garcia Bartels |first1 = N |last2 = Scheufele |first2 = R |last3 = Prosch |first3 = F |last4 = Schink |first4 = T |last5 = Proquitté |first5 = H |last6 = Wauer |first6 = PR |last7 = Blume-Peytavi |first7 = U |title = Effect of standardized skin care regimens on neonatal skin barrier function in different body areas |journal = Pediatric Dermatology |volume = 27 |issue = 1 |pages = 1–8 |date = February 23, 2010 |doi = 10.1111/j.1525-1470.2009.01068.x |pmid = 20199402 }}</ref>
In February 2013 [[Journal of Obstetric, Gynecologic, & Neonatal Nursing]] published a research by academics at [[University of Manchester|The University of Manchester]] that showed that washing newborn babies with Johnson’s Baby '''Top-to-Toe wash''' is just as safe as using water alone.<ref>{{Cite journal |pmc = 3664406 |title = Randomized, Controlled Trial Evaluating a Baby Wash Product on Skin Barrier Function in Healthy, Term Neonates |author = Tina Lavender |date = February 19, 2013 |website = ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/ |publisher = [[Journal of Obstetric, Gynecologic, & Neonatal Nursing]] |pages = 203–14|doi = 10.1111/1552-6909.12015|pmid = 23421327|display-authors = etal |volume=42}}</ref> Research has been sponsored by Johnson & Johnson "but carried out under strict, independent scientific protocols, including blind testing and peer review".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/discover/news/article/?id=9546 |title=Baby wash does not damage baby’s skin barrier function, study finds |date=February 19, 2013 |website=manchester.ac.uk/ |publisher=[[University of Manchester]] |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/6S2sHPnh5?url=http://www.manchester.ac.uk/discover/news/article/?id=9546 |archive-date=August 23, 2014 |accessdate=August 23, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>

'''LaborNet''' is a [[San Francisco]]-based "democratic communications" network for the [[labour movement]]. It was founded in 1991.
According to LaborNet's website, its "''founders believe that the new communication technology must be put to use to revitalize and rebuild the labor movement. To that end we established the first regular Labor News web page in the United States.''" [http://www.labornet.org/about.htm]
Currently, the initiative has been expanded, with "LaborNets" being also set up in other places like [[Canada]], [[United Kingdom]], [[Austria]], [[Germany]], [[Japan]] and [[Korea]]. LaborNet says it also works to defend the [[internet]] from [[censorship]] and the [[privatization]] of [[information]] "''that would limit and destroy our rights to communicate and build world unionism.''"
==External links== *[http://www.labornet.org/ LaborNet]

{{Refimprove|date=September 2014}} The following [[industrial design]]ers and [[product design]]ers are among those who are noted for their accomplishments in industrial or product design, and/or who have made extraordinary contributions to industrial-design education or philosophy.
This list is categorized by the main design movements of the twentieth century. Although many industrial designers of this list followed many such trends, they are listed under the movement they are most associated with.
== [[Arts and Crafts movement]] (1851–1914) == * [[Walter Crane]] * [[William R. Lethaby]] * [[Charles Rennie Mackintosh]] (1868–1929) * [[Arthur Heygate Mackmurdo]] * [[William Morris]] (1834–1896) * [[Charles Voysey (architect)|Charles Voysey]] * [[Philip Webb]]
== [[Art Nouveau]] (1870–1905) == Note - This category also includes preliminary work of the [[Wiener Werkstätte]] * [[Charles Robert Ashbee]] * [[Christopher Dresser]] * [[Henry Ford]] * [[Emile Gallé]] * [[Josef Hoffmann]] * [[Victor Horta]] * [[Archibald Knox (designer)|Archibald Knox]] * [[Louis Majorelle]] * [[Henry Van de Velde]]

{{Infobox software | title = Oracle Communications
MetaSolv Solution | logo = [[File:Oracle logo.svg|250px]] | logo alt = Oracle Corporation Logo | logo caption = Oracle Corporation | logo size = 250px | screenshot = | screenshot alt = | caption = | collapsible = | author = MetaSolv Software, Inc | developer = Jim Janicki (and others) | released = | discontinued = | ver layout = | latest release version = 6.3 | latest release date = | latest preview version = | latest preview date = | repo = | programming language = | operating system = | platform = | size = | language = | language count = | language footnote = | genre = [[Operations Support System]] | license = [[Proprietary software|Proprietary]] [[Commercial Software]] | alexa = | website = | standard = | AsOf = }} '''MetaSolv Solution''' (''also known as MetaSolv or MSS'') is an [[Operations Support System]] [[database application]] originally created by MetaSolv Software, Inc. for use by the telcommunications industry. The company was acquired by [[Oracle Corporation]], and Oracle still supports the application today under the umbrella of [[Oracle Corporation#Corporate structures|Oracle Communications]]. The software is used by many telecom companies (not just [[Telephone company|telephone]], but [[Internet service provider|ISPs]], [[List of cable television companies|cable companies]], and more).{{cite web |url=https://community.oracle.com/groups/metasolv-sig |title=MetaSolv User Group |website=Community.Oracle.com |publisher=Oracle |access-date=September 21, 2018}} == History == When MetaSolv was originally developed in the early [[1990s]], the new application was first referred to as '''ASAP''' (''Access Services and Provisioning''). ASAP provided a method for tracking [[Inventory|equipment inventory]], port consumption and circuit designs for engineering departments within telecom companies. But, by 1997, the need for tracking [[Work order|customer service orders]] was identified, and the system enhanced to provide for it. Along with order tracking, the need for [[Workflow|workflow]] management was also addressed. By the late 1990s, the application was rebranded by the company as '''TBS''' (''Telecom Business Solution'') from version 3.10 through version 4.11, until the introduction of the 5.0 version. At that time (''about 2003''), MetaSolv Inc again rebranded the application, this time to '''MetaSolv Solution''', also known as M/5. The latest release is often simply referred to simply as '''M6'''. MetaSolv Inc had several other products besides M6, and made efforts to provide seamless [[System integration|integration]] and connectivity between MetaSolv and those products in various ways. After Oracle acquired MetaSolv Inc (see below), Oracle absorbed all of MetaSolv Inc's products and continued the trend of integrating them. Even without those integrations, MetaSolv is a stand-alone OSS application that supports service provisioning through the entire life-cycle of customer and network development. == Oracle Acquisition == MetaSolv Software Inc. (''Nasdaq: MSLV'') was privately founded in 1992 soon becoming a leading provider of service fulfillment solutions designed to meet the needs of telecommunications providers. MetaSolv Inc became a publicly traded company offering an [[Initial public offering|IPO]] in 1999.{{cite web |url= https://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/company/metasolv-inc-10266-2893 |title= NASDAQ - MetaSolv Inc (MSLV) IPO |date= |website= NASDAQ |publisher= |access-date= July 25, 2018}} MetaSolv (''the company'') was acquired by Oracle in 2006 for $219 million. On December 15, 2006, a majority of MetaSolv stockholders approved Oracle's acquisition of MetaSolv Software Inc..{{cite web |url= http://www.orafaq.com/wiki/MetaSolv |title= Oracle FAQs - MetaSolv |date= December 2008 |last= Naude |first= Frank |website= OraFAQ |publisher= |access-date= July 26, 2018}} Oracle continues to offer and maintain the application today.{{cite web |url= https://www.oracle.com/corporate/acquisitions/metasolv/support.html |title= Oracle Acquisitions - Support for MetaSolv Products |date= |website= Oracle |publisher= |access-date= July 24, 2018}} == Description == === General Capabilities === MetaSolv Solution (''the software'') is an [[Oracle Database]] application sometimes described as "''Telco in a Box''".{{cite web |url= https://www.oracle.com/industries/communications/service-providers/products/metasolv-solution/index.html |title= Oracle Communications MetaSolv Solution |date= |website= Oracle |publisher= |access-date= July 26, 2018}} The system provides for many business processes common among all types of telecommunications businesses including: * Ordering (Regulated and Unregulated) * [[Workflow Management]] * [[Inventory Management]] * [[Telecommunications engineering|Network Engineering]] * Network Infrastructure Management * [[Service Provisioning]] * Trouble Management Typical implementation of MetaSolv within any telecom company often include users from Customer Care, Service Ordering, Engineering, Switching, Central Office and Field Technician departments. === Industry Standards === Early in the development of the application, MetaSolv Inc realized the need to implement common industry standard practices such as those provided today by '''iConectiv''' (''previously known as [[Telcordia Technologies]], but rebranded after [[Ericsson]] acquired them''). These standards included such things as standard equipment identifiers, [[Circuit ID|circuit identification]], location identification (''commonly called [[CLLI code]]''), connection codes (''also known as Network Channel codes''), rate codes, and much more. Across the industry, such standards are typically provided by iConectiv in the form of [[Common Language Information Services]]. By adding these standards to MetaSolv, the application more properly fit into the telecom OSS industry. Later however, companies expressed an interest in varying from industry standards. Releases after version 6.0 (6.1, 6.2, etc) included the ability to do so in some areas. === Interfacing and Reporting === Today, MetaSolv is often interfaced with other telecom company [[OSS/BSS]] systems through [[Application programming interface|APIs]] and other means. Since the software is a front-end [[database application]] with an Oracle database behind it, multiple off-the-shelf [[SQL]]-based reporting tools are used to support [[business intelligence]] needs in several departments. == See Also == {{Portal|Telecommunication|Computing}} * [[List of acquisitions by Oracle]] * [[:Category:Oracle software|List of Wikipedia Articles about Oracle Software]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == * [https://www.oracle.com/industries/communications/service-providers/products/metasolv-solution/index.html Oracle Communications MetaSolv Solution description page] * [http://www.oracle.com/us/industries/communications/communications-metasolv-ds-398152.pdf MetaSolv Datasheet] * [https://fenix.tecnico.ulisboa.pt/downloadFile/3779576328719/oracle-communications-metasolv-solution-whitepaper.pdf Oracle Communications MetaSolv Solution Overview whitepaper, Updated April 2007] * [https://community.oracle.com/groups/metasolv-sig Oracle Community - MetaSolv Users Group] {{oracle}} [[Category:Business software]][[Category:Database management systems]][[Category:Oracle software]][[Category:Oracle Database]][[Category:Telecommunications systems]]

{{multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=March 2010}} {{more footnotes|date=October 2013}} {{generalize|date=May 2014}} }} [[File:Courrier.jpg|thumb|Military message, 1904.]] [[File:Funkgerät R-147 IMG 1391.JPG|thumb|Soviet platoon radio set R-147]] [[File:3 men working on a portable phone switchboard.jpg|thumb|Middle 20th century field systems often required an [[Switchboard operator|operator]]]] '''Military communications''' or '''military signals''' involve all aspects of [[communication]]s, or conveyance of [[information]], by [[armed forces]]. Military communications span from pre-history to the present. The earliest military communications were delivered by [[Runner (soldier)|runners]]. Later, communications progressed to visual and audible signals, and then advanced into the electronic age. Examples from ''[[Jane's Military Communications]]'' include text, audio, facsimile, [[Military tactics|tactical]] ground-based communications, terrestrial microwave, [[tropospheric scatter]], naval, satellite communications systems and equipment, surveillance and signal analysis, encryption and security and direction-finding and jamming.<ref name=JMC>[[IHS Inc.|IHS]] [[Jane's]] [http://www.janes.com/products/janes/defence/systems/military-communications.aspx?pu=1&rd=janes_com Military Communications] Retrieved 2012-01-23</ref>
==History== In past centuries communicating a message usually required someone to go to the destination, bringing the message. Thus, the term "communication" often implied the ability to transport people and supplies. A place under [[siege]] was one that lost communication in both senses. The association between transport and messaging declined in recent centuries.
The first '''military communications''' involved the use of runners or the sending and receiving of simple [[wikt:signal|signals]] (sometimes [[cryptography|encoded]] to be unrecognizable). The first distinctive uses of military communications were called "signals". Modern units specializing in these tactics are usually designated as "[[signal corps]]". The Roman system of military communication (''[[cursus publicus]]'' or ''cursus vehicularis'') is an early example of this. Later, the terms "signals" and "[[signaler]]" became words referring to a highly-distinct military occupation dealing with general communications methods (similar to those in [[Civilian|civil]] use) rather than with [[weapons]].
Present-day military forces of an [[informational society]] conduct intense and complicated communicating activities on a daily basis, using modern [[telecommunications]] and [[computing]] methods. Only a small portion of these activities are directly related to combat actions.
Modern concepts of [[network-centric warfare]] (NCW) rely on [[Telecommunications network|network]]-oriented methods of communications and control to make existing forces more effective.
==Military communications equipment== Drums, horns, flags, and riders on horseback were some of the early methods the military used to send messages over distances. In the middle 20th century [[radio]] equipment came to dominate the field.
Many modern pieces of military communications equipment are built to both encrypt and decode [[Transmission (telecommunications)|transmissions]] and survive rough treatment in hostile climates. They use different [[frequency|frequencies]] to send signals to other radios and to satellites.
Military communications - or "comms" - are activities, equipment, techniques, and tactics used by the military in some of the most hostile areas of the earth and in challenging environments such as battlefields, on [[Radio in a box|land]], underwater and also in air. Military comms include command, control and communications and intelligence and were known as the C3I model before computers were fully integrated. The U.S. Army expanded the model to C4I when it recognized the vital role played by automated computer equipment to send and receive large, bulky amounts of data. {{Further information|C4ISTAR}}
The advent of distinctive signals led to the formation of the signal corps, a group specialized in the tactics of military communications. The signal corps evolved into a distinctive occupation where the [[signaler]] became a highly technical job dealing with all available communications methods including civil ones. {{citation needed|date=March 2013}}
In the modern world, most nations attempt to minimize the risk of war caused by miscommunication or inadequate communication. As a result, military communication is intense and complicated, and often motivates the development of advanced technology for remote systems such as satellites and aircraft, both manned and unmanned, as well as computers. Computers and their varied applications have revolutionized military comms. Although military communication is designed for warfare, it also supports intelligence-gathering and communication between adversaries, and thus sometimes prevents war. [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 101II-MW-5675-24, Übung zum Unternehmen "Seelöwe".jpg|alt=Man in uniform with headphones and throat microphone|thumb|Officer using radio, 1940]] There are six categories of military comms: the alert measurement systems, cryptography, military radio systems, nuclear command control, the signal corps, and network-centric warfare.
The alert measurement systems are various states of alertness or readiness for the armed forces used around the world during a state of war, act of terrorism or a military attack against a state. They are known by different acronyms, such as DEFCON, or defense readiness condition, used by the U.S. Armed Forces.
[[Cryptography]] is the study of methods of converting messages to a form unreadable except to one who knows how to decrypt them. This ancient military comms art gained new importance with the rise of radio systems whose signals traveled far and were easily intercepted. Cryptographic software is also widely used in civilian commerce.
== Commercial refile == In United States military communications systems, commercial refile refers to sending a military message via a commercial [[communications network]]. The [[message]] may come from a military [[telecommunications network|network]], such as a [[tape relay]] network, a point-to-point telegraph network, a [[Wireless telegraphy|radio-telegraph]] network, or the [[Defense Switched Network]].
Commercial refiling of a message will usually require a reformatting of the message, particularly the heading.
